tn.text: See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]]
It is clearly the woman's lover who is speaking.

The man describes the woman as a garden. On the night of their wedding, the man is finally able to fully enjoy the woman. He describes this as coming into his garden. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
The man calls the woman his sister because he loves her very much like he would love his sister. AT: "the one I love."

tn.ref: I have gathered my myrrh ... with my milk
tn.text: The man uses these images from a garden to indicate that he has been able to enjoy many different aspects of the woman.
plants that have a strong smell or taste
Here begins Part Four of the book

The young woman uses euphemisms to describe her dream so that it can be interpreted in two different ways: 1) the woman describes a dream about a night when her lover came to visit her at her house; and 2) the woman describes a dream about starting to sleep with her lover. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
AT: "but my mind was awake." AT: "but my feelings were active." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to opening a door but it can also be interpreted as a sexual request. AT: "Open the door for me" or "Open yourself to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
A term of affection. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:04:09|4:9]].
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:09|1:0]].
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:14|2:14]].
"my perfect one" or "my faithful one" or "my innocent one"
drops of water or mist that form during the cool of the night when the temperature drops

tn.ref: my hair with the night's dampness
tn.text: The wet night air makes the man's hair wet because he is standing outside.

tn.ref: my head is wet with dew, my hair with the night's dampness
tn.text: These two lines mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
thin linen clothing that people wore on their skin

tn.ref: must I put it on again?
tn.text: AT: "I do not want to get dressed again." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Possible interpretations are 1) the young woman had washed her feet so that she could go to bed or 2) The word "feet" is sometimes used as a euphemism to refer to a woman's private parts. AT: "I washed myself." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: My beloved put in his hand through the opening of the door latch
tn.text: Possible interpretations are 1) the lover reaches into the house through a hole in the door in order to open the door or 2) this describes the start of the sexual act. In this context, "hand" serves as a euphemism for a man's private parts.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:12|1:12]].
"door lock"

tn.ref: I got up to open the door for my beloved
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the young woman got out of bed in order to let her beloved into the house or 2) "I prepared myself in order to open up myself sexually to my beloved." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The words "hands" and "fingers" likely refer to the genitals of a woman.
"with liquid myrrh"
The young woman continues to describe her dream.

tn.ref: I opened the door for my beloved
tn.text: AT: "I opened myself to my beloved." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:12|1:13]].

tn.ref: My heart sank; I became despondent
tn.text: "My soul left, when he spoke." AT: "When he spoke, I felt like I had died." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
those who watch and guard the city at night
The word "me" refers to the young woman.
"beat me" or "hit me"
"injured me"
"the men who guard the walls"
an outdoor overgarment that people wore over their other clothing on their upper body when they went out in public.

tn.ref: I want you to promise, daughters of Jerusalem
tn.text: See how you translated "I want you to promise, daughters of Jerusalem," in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:07|2:7]].

tn.ref: sick because of my love for him
tn.text: Her love is so strong that she feels sick. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you who are beautiful among women
tn.text: See how you translated "most beautiful of women" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:08|1:8]].
"What makes your beloved better"

tn.ref: that you ask us to take an oath like this
tn.text: "and causes you to have us take this oath"
See the oath in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:05:08|5:8]].
It is implied that the woman is describing the skin of her beloved. AT: "has radiant and ruddy skin"
"is completely healthy" or "is pure." The beloved has skin that does not have any problems.
a healthy color of the skin that is brownish red
"the best of 10,000." AT: "better than anyone else" or "no one else is like him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: His head is the purest gold
tn.text: The beloved's head is as precious to the woman as the purest gold. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a bird with very black feathers
The young woman continues to describe her beloved.
See how you translated "your eyes are like doves" in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:15|1:15]].
The woman might be using this image to say that her beloved's eyes are moist like the streams of water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"washing themselves in milk." The doves represent the beloved's pupils. These are surrounded by the rest of his eyes, which are as white as milk. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
His eyes are so beautiful that they look like jewels that a craftsman has carefully put in place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The young woman continues to describe her beloved.
This explains that his cheeks are like beds of spices because they both give off wonderful smells. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a garden or part of a garden where people grow spices
"that give off wonderful smells."
The woman probably compares his lips with lilies because they are beautiful and smell wonderful. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:02:16|2:16]].
"that drip with the best myrrh." His lips are moist and have a wonderful smell like myrrh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The young woman continues to describe her beloved.

tn.ref: His arms are rounded gold set with jewels
tn.text: "His arms are cylinders of gold that have jewels all over them." The woman uses this image to say that his arms are beautiful and precious. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: his abdomen is ivory covered with sapphires
tn.text: "his belly is smooth ivory that has sapphires all over it." The woman uses this image to say that his belly is beautiful and precious. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
the white tusk or tooth of an animal that is similar to bone. People use ivory to make smooth and shiny pieces of art.
Sapphire is a kind of clear, valuable stone. This kind of sapphire probably has a yellow or golden color.
The young woman continues to describe her beloved.

tn.ref: His legs are pillars of marble
tn.text: His legs are strong and beautiful like marble pillars. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a very strong stone that has many different colors and people and polish it to make it very smooth

tn.ref: set on bases of pure gold
tn.text: AT: "that have bases of pure gold as their foundation." His feet are valuable and precious like bases of pure gold that support the pillars of marble. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"he looks like Lebanon." Lebanon was a very beautiful area with many mountains and trees. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"as desirable as the cedars" or "excellent like the cedars
The young woman continues to describe her beloved.
The woman uses this image to describe the sweet kisses of her beloved or the sweet words that he says. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"every part of is lovely" or "all of him is lovely"

tn.ref: This is my beloved, and this is my friend
tn.text: The word "This" refers to the person that the woman has just finished describing. You could also translate this phrase as "That is what my beloved is like, and that is what my friend is like."
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:sng:01:05|1:5]].
